content.text: To formally derive the Golden Rule, we need several logical tools: deontic operators for obligation and permission, and a way to express 'what I would want' and 'what I do to others'.

content.definition: W_a(φ) means 'agent a wants φ to be the case.' This captures the 'as you would have them do' part of the Golden Rule.
Do(a, b, A) means 'agent a does action A to agent b.' This lets us distinguish who acts and who is affected.

content.text: The Golden Rule can now be stated: If ¬W_me(Do(x, me, A)) — I don't want A done to me — then O(¬Do(me, x, A)) — I ought not do A to others. In symbols: ¬W_me(Do(x, me, A)) → O(¬Do(me, x, A)).

content.question: What does ¬W_me(Do(x, me, harm)) express?
options: I don't want others to harm me
content.explanation: W_me means 'I want', the ¬ negates it, and Do(x, me, harm) means 'x does harm to me'. Together: I don't want x to harm me.
